summary: This is an email chain from July 2020 between a federal prosecutor and attorneys representing alleged Epstein victims. The prosecutor expresses interest in speaking with a client who has changed their mind about cooperating, requests basic information and lawsuit filings, and proposes an attorney proffer. The chain is initiated by a news article about an accuser's reaction to Ghislaine Maxwell's arrest.

persons.name: Jordan Merson
persons.context: Attorney representing nine clients who are alleged Epstein accusers; he initiates contact with the prosecutor indicating a client is now ready to help.

persons.name: Jesse Mautner
persons.context: Attorney at Merson Law, copied on the email correspondence regarding Epstein accuser clients.

persons.name: Rossmiller
persons.context: The government prosecutor corresponding with defense attorneys Jordan Merson and Jesse Mautner about speaking to their clients who are Epstein accusers.

connections.description: Both are attorneys at Merson Law firm, copied together on correspondence regarding their clients.
Attorney-client relationship proxy; Merson represents accusers and is communicating with prosecutor Rossmiller about potential cooperation.

events.title: News article on accuser reaction to Maxwell arrest
events.description: New York Post publishes article titled "This Epstein accuser is 'ecstatic' over Ghislaine Maxwell's arrest," which prompts attorney Jordan Merson to reach out to prosecutors.

events.title: Prosecutor acknowledges attorney contact
events.description: Prosecutor responds to initial contact from attorneys Jordan Merson and Jesse Mautner, indicating they will likely reach out the following week.

events.title: Prosecutor requests client information and proposes proffer
events.description: Prosecutor follows up on email chain, notes a change in position from one of Merson's clients, requests lawsuit filings and client names, and proposes an attorney proffer as the next step.

events.title: Previous communication indicating non-cooperation
events.description: In January 2020, attorney Jordan Merson advised the government that none of his nine clients were interested in speaking with them.

keyFacts: Attorney Jordan Merson represents nine clients who are alleged Epstein accusers.
As of January 2020, none of Merson's nine clients were willing to speak with the government, but by July 2020 at least one had changed their mind.
The government prosecutor is seeking the names of the clients and copies of any lawsuits filed on their behalf to avoid conflict and prepare for a potential attorney proffer.
The correspondence was triggered by a July 2, 2020, New York Post article about an Epstein accuser's reaction to Ghislaine Maxwell's arrest.
